PostValue.explanation: This is a practical outreach/solicitation post offering MEL (monitoring, evaluation, learning) and Theory-of-Change support to EA orgs. For the EA community it has modest importance: if the service is high-quality and adopted it could improve planning and impact measurement at some organisations, helping them make better decisions and allocation of resources, but it is not foundational to EA theory or large-scale strategy. For general humanity it is essentially irrelevant — it affects a narrow operational niche and has no broad societal implications unless it scaled dramatically.

PostRobustness.actionable_feedback:
1) Be explicit about what you’re offering and what you want from people. Right now readers don’t know the scope, typical timeline, or expected cost of the MEL/ToC support (and the “Fill out the form” link isn’t visible in the post text). Add a one‑paragraph summary (1–2 sentences) of typical deliverables, an estimated duration and cost model (paid / pro bono / sliding scale), and what information the form collects and how long it takes. This reduces friction and avoids irrelevant signups.

2) Add clear data/privacy and consent language. You say you’ll “use the list” to show demand to funders — say exactly what that means: who will see individual responses, whether you’ll share organization names with funders or only anonymized counts, whether respondents will be contacted, and how long you’ll keep the data. Add an opt‑in checkbox for being on a contact/waitlist and an option to keep responses confidential or anonymous. This is important for trust and for compliance with organizational policies.

3) Define prioritisation and urgency criteria. You currently say you’ll prioritise paid projects and “high‑priority” cases but don’t define either. Provide brief, concrete selection criteria (e.g., evidence of impact scale, time‑sensitivity, lack of existing MEL capacity, ability to pay) and a short timeline for follow‑up (e.g., when the waiting list will be reviewed and how decisions will be communicated). That will reduce perceptions of bias and help organisations self‑select appropriately.

Suggested small edits you can paste in: a) a one‑line service description at the top, b) a 1–2 sentence data‑use/consent blurb before the form link, and c) a short bullet list of the prioritisation criteria and what “urgent” means. Making these three changes should materially increase useful responses and reduce confusion or pushback.
PostRobustness.improvement_potential: The feedback pinpoints several concrete, high-impact omissions (unclear scope/timeline/cost, missing data‑use/consent details, and vague prioritisation) that are likely to cause irrelevant signups, trust issues, or perceived bias. These are not fatal to the post but are important, fixable ‘own goals’ the authors would likely be embarrassed about once pointed out. The suggested fixes are short and practical, so implementing them should materially improve response quality without bloating the post.

PostAuthorAura.explanation: No known presence in the EA/rationalist community up to 2024-06 (no notable posts, talks, or citations on EA Forum, LessWrong, 80,000 Hours, or major EA-affiliated outlets). Also not a publicly recognized author or figure more broadly — likely an obscure/private individual or pseudonym. If you have links or context, I can reassess.

PostClarity.explanation: Clear, direct call-to-action with useful links, contact details, and a concise explanation of purpose (building a waiting list and refining services). Weaknesses are minor: a few typos/awkward phrasings, some jargon (MEL/ToC) that isn’t defined for newcomers, and missing specifics (no deadline/year for funding mention, no brief description of what the form asks or what counts as 'urgent'). Overall easy to understand and appropriately concise.

PostNovelty.explanation: This is largely a routine outreach/posting: offering MEL/ToC services, asking interested organizations to fill a form, building a waitlist, and offering limited pro bono work are all very common practices within EA and nonprofit communities. Within the EA Forum audience this is not novel at all (many consultancies, capacity‑building offers, and intake/waitlist posts exist). For the general public it’s slightly more specific because MEL/ToC and targeted EA support are specialized concepts, but the overall idea (service solicitation and client intake) remains familiar.

PostInferentialSupport.explanation: This post is primarily an outreach/ask rather than a sustained argumentative claim, so its reasoning is simple and generally coherent: they collected prior positive feedback, want to gather demand, and offer limited pro bono capacity. That makes the logical structure fine but minimal. However, empirical support is weak — the post asserts "a lot of positive, encouraging feedback" and claims demand without providing data, examples, or credentials (no testimonials, numbers, or past project outcomes). Overall the main thrust (build a waiting list / solicit interest) is reasonable and appropriate for the forum, but the post provides little evidence to substantiate broader claims about demand or impact, limiting how well-supported it is beyond being a plausible call-to-action.

PostExternalValidation.validation_notes: Most of the post's empirical claims are verifiable and supported. I found the earlier EA Forum post (Feb 13, 2025) by the same team announcing Salt & Impact, which explicitly states they had ~three months of runway (consistent with 'funding runs out in April'), offered five free workshops / one ToC process, and solicited feedback — and that post received multiple positive answers and upvotes (supporting the 'positive, encouraging feedback' claim). Community-roundup posts (EA Organization Updates) also record Salt Impact gauging interest and offering limited pro-bono slots. I could not find a separate EA Forum post matching the exact title & author string you quoted (Clara Jule Roberts) for the follow-up form post, but multiple independent sources confirm the team, their outreach to EA orgs, and limited pro-bono capacity. Minor uncertainty remains about the exact authorship/URL of the specific follow-up post and the precise current status of funding after April 2025 (the cited runway statement was time-limited).
sources: EA Forum post: '(How) can we help the EA-space with our MEL/impact Consulting best?' by Teresa Jakovlev, Feb 13, 2025 (Salt & Impact — states 3 months runway; offers 5 free workshops and a ToC process).
EA Forum — 'EA Organization Updates: March 2025' (notes Salt Impact is gauging interest from EA orgs and has limited pro-bono slots; corroborates outreach).
EA Forum search/result page referencing the Feb 13, 2025 post and showing community answers/upvotes (examples of positive/encouraging feedback).
EAGxPrague 2025 programme listing (shows Clara Jule Roberts as presenting on maximizing organizational impact — corroborates Clara's involvement in the initiative).
Domain info for salt-impact.com (WHOIS/IP record summary) indicating the Salt & Impact website exists / was registered (supports claim there is a dedicated project website).
